abstract.p: Adjusting houseplants to indoors during fall described (S)

block.p: If you rushed houseplants indoors when temperatures plunged, help them adjust to their drastically different conditions. During the day, move them outside to progressively shadier spots, and then back indoors at night. Inspect plants closely: check the undersides of leaves and stems for aphids, scale and mealybugs, and drainage holes for slugs, sowbugs and earwigs. Spray with a hard stream of water to dislodge pests, or wash with a solution of a few drops of mild soap diluted in a gallon of water.

Save major rose pruning for winter or early spring, but look for borer holes in canes and cut out infested wood. Harvest hips from rugosa and dog roses to use for tea and cooking. Remove stem and blossom ends, cut in half and remove seeds. Dry in a barely warm oven or a food dehydrator.
